704914f-a.text:
87 to 99 Hicks Street, east side, south from Orange
to Pineapple Streets.
June 11, 1927
P. L. Sperr
704914f-a.folder: Hicks Street & Orange Street, Brooklyn, NY

706135f-a.text:
Orange Street, east from Hicks Street. The view shows a modern addition, the Institute (in the foreground) of the old Plymouth Church,formerly the church of Henry Ward Beecher.
1928.
C. P. Cushing.
Ewing Galloway.
706135f-a.folder: Orange Street & Hicks Street, Brooklyn, NY

706139f-a.text:
Orange Street, between Hicks and Henry Streets. The view shows the statue of Henry Ward Beecher, by Gutzon Borglum, at the Congregational Plymouth Church.
1928.
Ewing Galloway.
706139f-a.folder: Orange Street & Hicks Street, Brooklyn, NY

706137f-b.text:
Orange Street, north side, between Hicks and Henry Streets, showing the old Plymouth Church, built in 1849, from which Henry Ward Beecher, Brooklyn's famous preacher, delivered his sermons.  Abraham Lincoln, who was a personal friend of the minister, came here to hear his sermons. Walter Damrosch,noted composer and orchestra conductor, at one time served here as musical director under Beecher. View 1 is east from Hicks Street; view 2, west from Henry Street.

For additional pictures see the Cranberry Street file for views of that side of the church edifice, and for additional data see "The New York Times," October 5, 1940.

April 4, 1932
Views 1,2,3

F.L.Sperr
706137f-b.folder: Orange Street & Hicks Street, Brooklyn, NY

704913f-a.text:
75-77 Hicks Street, at and adjoining the N.E. corner of Orange Street, showing the home (No. 77) of the Rev. S.B. Halliday, adjoining the corner. This site is now, 1929, occupied by the Plymouth Institute.
About 1895.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
704913f-a.folder: Hicks Street & Orange Street, Brooklyn, NY

704915f-a.text:
Hicks Street, at the N.W. corner of Orange Street, showing a house razed in 1886. It is said that Joel Bunce, the first Postmaster of Brooklyn, (about 1819) occupied it. It was also occupied for some years by the artist Thomas Nast.
About 1886.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
704915f-a.folder: Hicks Street & Orange Street, Brooklyn, NY

704916f-b.text:
(1)
Hicks Street, north from Orange Street. On the right is a portion of Plymouth Institute, connected with the Plymouth Church, on Orange Street. The old peaked-roof house (white wall) was the home and cracker bakery of D. K. Ducker, at the N. E. corner of Cranberry Street. The firm later became known as Hatfield and Ducker.
April, 1925
Eugene L. Armbruster
(2)
The same, at a later date, viewing across Orange Street and showing Plymouth Institute in its entirety.
June 11, 1927
P. L. Sperr
704916f-b.folder: Hicks Street & Orange Street, Brooklyn, NY

706132f-b.text:
Orange Street, adjoining the N. E. corner of Hicks Street, showing the Plymouth Institute and the Henry Ward Beecher monument. The statue of the famous Brooklyn preacher was executed
by Gutson Borglum.
View 1: June 11, 1927
View 2: April 4, 1932
P. L. Sperr

706133f.text:
Orange Street, at the N.E. corner of Hicks Street, showing the home of the Rev. L.B. Halliday. In 1929 the Plymouth Church buildings occupied the site.
